aToolTip: Review of the overall strategies and drivers of an organization’s research data program.
bToolTip: The tactical management positioning in an organization for effective research data management throughout the research data lifecycle.
cToolTip: The generation of raw research data, both experimentally and computationally, within an organization, and the collection or acquisition of research data produced outside of an organization.
dToolTip: The actions performed on generated or externally acquired research data to yield processed research data, typically using software, from which observations and conclusions can be made.
eToolTip: How raw and processed research data are disseminated, used, and reused within an organization and any constraints or encouragements to use/reuse. It also includes the dissemination, use, and reuse of raw and processed research data outside of an organization.
fToolTip: The end-of-use and end-of-life provisions for research data in an organization and includes records management, archiving, and safe disposal.

aToolTip: An exercise to define the objectives of, and responsible individuals for, various aspects of research data management (RDM).

Vision: An aspirational state an organization wishes to achieve with respect to RDM.  Policy: A set of recommended and sometimes mandatory high-level principles that establish a guiding framework for RDM. [5,6]

An RDM infrastructure (RDMI) of human and capital resources that supports data-related activities, e.g., policies, planning, and sharing, as well as practices and projects, e.g., data acquisition, control, and protection.

A set of core beliefs that function as guides to what is seen as good and important in an organization and the guiding principles that provide an organization with purpose and direction. (Values ideally include diversity, equity, and inclusivity.) [10, 11]
A clear statement that indicates exactly what benefits an organization will derive from an RDM program. [12]
An evaluation of the types of data that are critical to accomplish the stated goals of an organization.
A clear statement of the need for, use of, and benefit derived from, research data.
The extent to which an organization supports the internal adoption and use of the FAIR data principles.
Components of the RDMI within an organization that enable data to be prepared and processed for its ultimate application, including reuse.
The application of rigorous analyses and oversight to ensure that data assets meet the needs of users. [13]
The practice of protecting and properly handling sensitive data, including personal, proprietary, and confidential data

Moral principles pertaining to data practices, e.g., analysis and dissemination, that have the potential to adversely impact people and society (e.g., to minimize bias and maintain the privacy of personal data). See also the Global Data Ethics Project. [15–17]
The practice of protecting digital information from unauthorized access, denial of access, theft, or corruption throughout its entire lifecycle. [18]

A function that provides organization capabilities for archiving management such that data products can be grouped, searched and identified for retrieval, statistics and reorganization. Also, a list of available items stored and/or controlled in a storage warehouse system. [15, pg 19]
A systematic process for the identification and evaluation of potential threats to and vulnerabilities of an organization’s data assets, e.g., unauthorized access to sensitive data.  [20]

A process for the development and implementation  of appropriate strategies to control, reduce, or eliminate potential threats to and vulnerabilities of an organization’s data assets as identified by a risk assessment. [21]

Data sharing agreement: A formal contract that details what data are being shared and the appropriate use for the data. Licensing agreement: A formal contract that states the purpose and duration of access being provided to the recipient licensee along with restriction and security protocols the recipient licensee of the data must follow. [22, 23]

text: Social license for use and reuse
aToolTip: An unwritten agreement whereby a group of public stakeholders accept that certain datasets may be applied for purposes other than those for which the data were originally intended, e.g., healthcare data. [24]

Legal requirements as set by an authoritative entity (e.g., local and national regions) concerning the dissemination of data by an organization and subsequent use of the data by other organizations.  [25]
The job functions and obligations that enable the establishment of a desired data culture and reward structure.
Processes and practices that provide acknowledgement and rewards for good RDM at all levels in an organization.
Recognition of the benefits that staff performing data-centric jobs or functions provide to an organization.
Career advancements that are linked to good research processes, practices, and outcomes.

For research: The condition resulting from adherence to professional values and practices when conducting, reporting, applying, and disseminating results of the work.[27] For data: The accuracy, completeness, and quality of data as they are maintained over time and across formats.[28]
Guidelines that allow digital objects (e.g., data, algorithms, and workflows) to be Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, and Reusable. [29]
Ongoing infrastructural support to sustain FAIR data principles and practices.

text: Incentives and impact for sharing and reuse
aToolTip: Staff recognition and rewards for widespread dissemination and application of research data and the beneficial effects of such dissemination.
Barriers that limit dissemination of data, e.g., misinterpretation and misuse of data by others, lack of recognition, and the effort required for sharing.

The CARE (Collective benefit, Authority to control, Responsibility, and Ethics) Principles for Indigenous Data Governance are people and purpose-oriented, reflecting the crucial role of data in advancing Indigenous innovation and self-determination. (These principles complement the existing FAIR principles for indigenous data governance.)   Ethics: Moral principles pertaining to data practices, e.g., analysis and dissemination, that have the potential to adversely impact people and society (e.g., to minimize bias and maintain the privacy of personal data). [15, 30]
A catalog of an organization's capabilities in essential data processes.

text: Workforce preparedness in new and advanced technologies
aToolTip: Assessment of needs for and provision of training in the skills and expertise of an organization's staff pertinent to novel and leading-edge areas of research, e.g., AI.
In-classroom, on-line, and/or hands-on instruction for staff to attain the skills and expertise required to manage data across all lifecycles.

text: HR’s supporting role in workforce development and training
aToolTip: Involvement of an organization's HR department in establishing and implementing instructional courses for staff to expand their skill sets and expertise in research data programs and RDM.
Documented approaches for recruitment, advancement, and retention of staff in data-centric jobs in an organization and expansion of data-related skills and expertise for all technical jobs.
Entities that provide financial support for research data programs and RDM infrastructure (e.g., capital and human resources).
Sustained financial support for research data activities and RDM infrastructure.
Provision of sufficient resources to support RDM staff and researchers engaged in RDM activities.
Individuals, groups, and organizations that have an interest or stake in RDM or research data activities in general and in particular domains. [31]
Ways by which information about data and data management are shared and discussed.

Partner: Two or more organizations or individuals that share responsibility and control of ideas, processes, and outcomes of research data activities.  Partnership: An agreement between organizations and individuals to collaborate on such activities.. [32]

text: Engagement across knowledge domains and sectors
aToolTip: Interactions among groups or individuals having expertise in different specific, specialized disciplines or fields, or expertise in different technology areas. [33]
The practice of including all types of people or ideas and treating them all fairly and equally. [34]
Solutions for data tasks (e.g., data transfer, storage, and analytics) and the organizations or individuals deriving value from such solutions. [35]
The job functions and obligations for tracking data assets.
Person empowered to grant access to data assets, e.g., a Chief Data Officer.

text: Centralized inventory of services, groups, and resources
aToolTip: An organization-wide catalog of elements supporting data-related activities at various levels of an organization, including capital (e.g., HPC), virtual (e.g., domain repositories), and human (e.g., Data Steward and AI interest group) components.

The historical, documented record of a data asset that contains details on its origin—where, when, how, and by whom it was generated/acquired/processed—and on all alterations to the data asset. [15, pg 24,31]
Approaches for providing financial support for data-related activities and infrastructure, including direct, (e.g., grants, contracts, and institutional), overhead, or mixed. [38]
Entities that provide financial support for research data activities and infrastructure, e.g., capital and human resources.
Methods to determine the financial requirements of various data activities and infrastructure (e.g., cost-benefit analysis, market analysis, and decision trees).
A systematic approach to estimating the strengths and weaknesses of alternative actions to determine options which provide the best approach to achieving benefits while preserving savings. [39]
Identification of funds required for each data activity in a project (e.g., hardware, software, and staffing for data generation), or for an RDM infrastructure (e.g., centralized data services).
Funds required after establishment of an RDM infrastructure (e.g., technology refresh and maintenance) or for later-stage data activities (e.g., long-term preservation).

Costs incurred in assuring that new staff with appropriate skills and expertise are hired for specific data activities and that existing staff attain new and advanced skills through instructional courses.

Documents that provide sufficient detail on the following topics: Administrative Data, Data Collection, Documentation and Metadata, Ethics and Legal Compliance, Storage and Backup, Selection and Preservation, Data Sharing, and Responsibilities and Resources. DMPs are referred to herein as a research data "roadmaps." [40]

text: Purpose/intent of research study and context of anticipated data use
aToolTip: Clear articulation of research objectives in terms of data products that are essential to address specific research and/or technical requirements.

text: Specification of data objects, metadata, analysis tools, and workflows throughout the lifecycle
aToolTip: Detailed descriptions of all information, processes, software, and hardware required from conception to completion of a research data project.
Research data roadmap documents in a form that can be used and understood by a computer. [41]

text: Linkage of DMPs to administrative records
aToolTip: Interconnection of a research data roadmaps to operational data, e.g., agreements, transactions.

text: Data organization in, e.g., a database and a repository, to facilitate future access
aToolTip: The practice of categorizing, classifying, and storing data with sufficient detail and specificity such that the data are readily discoverable and usable by others. [42]
In-class, on-line, and/or hands-on instruction for staff to attain the skills and knowledge required to manage data in a research study.

Quantitative data are numerical data, e.g., measurements and some controlled observations and questionnaires. Qualitative data are defined as non-numerical data, e.g., text, video, photographs, or audio recordings. [43]

text: Measurements, including images, audio recordings, and photos/videos
aToolTip: A quantity in various formats, including numerical, visual, and auditory.
A fact or occurrence often involving measurement with instruments. [44]
A list of questions aimed for extracting specific data from a particular group of people. [45]
A computer-based application that converts inputs into outputs to support the user in one or more research tasks. [46]
A representation, pattern, or mathematical description that can help scientists replicate a system, process, or research result. [47]

Comprehensive information that accompanies a dataset, including all associated metadata, data dictionary, description of methods and instruments [and software used to generate/collect and] process the data, and other supporting data (e.g., duplicate sample results, replicate analyses). [48]
A tangible object that may observed or tested to determine its properties or characteristics.
Material assembled to explain and describe research results or processes to an audience.

text: Organizational support for making data more FAIR
aToolTip: Institutional resources to improve the extent of "FAIRness" of data. (FAIRness is used herein to denote a continuum state ranging from no FAIR aspects to fully FAIR.)

text: Identification of methods/guidelines vis-à-vis FAIR principles
aToolTip: An exercise to locate techniques and recommended procedures related to FAIRness.
Requirements and needs by which decisions are made regarding what information to generate, collect, and document in a research study.
Specification of the requisite types and characteristics of selected information.
The degree to which data and metadata are meant to comply with the FAIR data principles.

text: Methods to capture and store data/metadata
aToolTip: Techniques or means by which data/metadata are collected, recorded, and preserved.
The overall structure of data about the data. Two examples of general-purpose metadata schema are Dublin Core and MODS (Metadata Object Description Schema). [50, 51]
A set of principles that are formulated from specific strategies, rules, models, and guidelines for the management and flow of a dataset throughout its lifecycle.
Methodology for translating raw data into useable information. Specific methods include, e.g., data preparation, validation, sorting, aggregation, analysis, and reporting.
The process of managing data in a structured manner. It involves collecting, organizing, and processing data so that it can be used for various purposes. [52]
A detailed description or scaled representation of the relationships and data flow between different components of an RDM system, typically in the form of a diagram or flowchart. [53]
A laboratory information management system (LIMS) is a software system developed to support laboratory operations (e.g., track specimens and workflows and aggregate data). [54]
Methods whereby, and locations wherein, data are saved and from which data can be retrieved.
The actions of tracking and controlling changes in the hardware and software components, e.g., updates and version control. [55]

The capability to communicate, execute programs, or transfer data among different RDM systems in a useful and meaningful manner that requires the user to have little or no knowledge of the unique characteristics of those systems. [58]
Features of the architecture that protect data from unauthorized access, denial of access, corruption, or theft throughout their entire lifecycles. [18]
Standards relevant to data architecture, including schema (e.g., based on SQL, JSON), format (e.g., JSON, XML), and APIs (e.g., Google Search for the web).
Essential resources required to accomplish the objectives of research projects and RDM (e.g., centralized infrastructure, appropriate training, and support staff).
Items, e.g., instruments, methods, utility software, and APIs, that enable research.

text: Models that connect infrastructure to data processes and workflow
aToolTip: A detailed description or scaled representation of the relationships between data tasks and movement and the hardware and software components in an RDMI. [53]

The capability to seamlessly communicate, execute programs, or transfer data among various functional components .that requires the user to have little or no knowledge of the unique characteristics of those components. [58]

Globally unique, persistent, and resolvable identifiers of operational scientific instruments enable research data to be persistently associated with such crucial metadata, helping to set data into context. The Research Data Alliance Working Group Persistent Identification of Instruments (PIDINST) developed a metadata schema and prototyped schema implementation and demonstrated the viability of the proposed solution in practice. [59]

text: Sustainability of data vis-à-vis obsolete infrastructure
aToolTip: Concerns regarding the ability to reproduce and reuse data if the hardware and software components become outdated or non-functional.
The degree of protection of data from unauthorized access, denial of access, corruption, or theft provided by the hardware and software. [18]
Personnel with the appropriate skills and knowledge to maintain and update the hardware and software infrastructure as needed, and personnel to interface with researchers using the infrastructure.

text: Criteria, i.e., general vs. domain-specific standards
aToolTip: Requirements and needs by which decisions are made regarding the type of research standard, i.e., broadly applicable or limited to a particular field of research.

Origins of accepted practices consisting of discrete, reusable components, e.g., data types, identifiers, schemas, and formats. Examples include the Dublin Core Metadata Initiative and Schema.org. [60]

Guidelines that provide sufficient information to allow all users to readily evaluate the degree of “fitness for purpose” of the data. Key data quality components include completeness, accuracy, integrity, consistency, and timeliness. [15, pg 26, 57]

Community-based data and metadata standards are typically long-term endeavors with many different players and types of efforts. Such standards facilitate reuse of data integrative analysis and comparison to other datasets and linkage of data with other research products, such as scholarly material, algorithms and software. [63]
Statement of project objectives; list of accomplishments demonstrating that these objectives were met.

text: Metrics for tracking use and impact measures, including reuse
aToolTip: Quantitative and qualitative indicators of positive influence or outcomes, (e.g., number of citations of a dataset and anecdotal evidence of reuse of a dataset). [64]

text: Methods to share and reuse data/metadata
aToolTip: Approaches to disseminate data/metadata and to facilitate reusability of data/metadata, (e.g., use of open repositories and maximizing the FAIRness of data).

text: Allocation of credit to project team members
aToolTip: Properly documenting and recognizing each team member's contributions to a project. [65]

text: Promotion of data to communities of interest
aToolTip: Modes to communicate the existence and location of datasets to targeted groups, e.g., special-topic data publications and presentations at topical workshops.
The process of working with other institutions or organizations on a shared activity (e.g., informal collaborations, formal partnerships, and agreements).

text: Requests for additional data from community
aToolTip: Soliciting data contributions from partners and stakeholders on areas of mutual interest.

text: Identification of responsible parties for access
aToolTip: A determination of those individuals authorized to both prohibit and permit access to sensitive data.

text: Ease of maintenance and implementation of records
aToolTip: The extent to which sensitive data can be kept up to date and made accessible to authorized individuals and groups.
Efforts by organizations to ensure that they are aware of and take steps to conform to relevant laws, policies, and regulations concerning sensitive data (e.g., medical records). [66]

Data that needs to be controlled due to certain risks. Personally Identifiable Information (PII) is any representation of information that permits the identity of an individual to whom the information applies to be reasonably inferred by either direct or indirect means. [67]

Restricting release of data to specific legal circumstances and often requiring notification to the data provider. Intellectual Property (IP) refers to certain exclusive rights granted by law to the owner of, e.g., a novel data product. [68]
Legal agreement that allows one party to use another party's data subject to certain conditions.

text: Measurements, including images, audio recordings, photos/videos
Infrastructure to assure the greatest data integrity
Aggregation of data evaluated by experts
Guidelines/methodologies for each aspect: F, A, I, R
Standards development organizations vs. community consensus
Integrated development environments, e.g., Jupyter, RStudio
Persistent identifiers (e.g., DOI, ORCID, ARK, ROR, PIDINST, Handles)
Laboratory notebooks, e.g., electronic and paper
Decisions regarding the need for additional data
Updates to datasets and new software versions
Quality measures and assessment vis-à-vis fit for purpose
Peer review of datasets and metadata
Reference data/digital objects in journal articles
Mitigation of disincentives for data publishing
Mitigation of barriers and economic constraints
Encouragement and support for sharing, use, and reuse
Constraints and restrictions on data use and sharing
Extensibility across communities, including machine-based interactions
Capture of insights from ML and use of these to improve datasets for future AI applications
Migration strategies and mitigation against data loss
Media to store and preserve data
Recognition of removed data, i.e., tombstone page

aToolTip:
The policies, procedures, and processes pertaining to authority, control,
and shared decision-making (planning, monitoring, and enforcement) over the management of data assets
The policies, procedures, and processes to manage and monitor an organization’s regulatory [and] legal responsibilities and risks pertaining to data.
yToolTip: Considerations for Data Governance—Legal and Regulatory Compliance

aToolTip: The collective beliefs and behaviors of the people in an organization concerning the value and management of research data. Practices designed to recognize the advantages and accomplishments of sharing data.
Training to provide staff with the necessary skills and expertise for data-related activities and RDM. Includes leadership support and formal and informal training.
The distribution and longevity of funding to attain and maintain robust research data programs and RDM infrastructure.
Outreach and interactions among organizations or individuals with shared goals or interests concerning research data activities or RDM

A complete, fully documented step-by-step history of a data asset in an organization, i.e., who has possession of a data asset, at what time, and for what purpose, at all times throughout the lifecycle of the data asset.
yToolTip: Considerations for Chain of Control (Custody of Data)

aToolTip: Factors to consider in estimating or assessing the costs associated with all research data and RDM activities over the data lifecycle.
yToolTip: Considerations for Financial Aspects of Planning

aToolTip: The process of organizing and specifying objectives and activities throughout the research data lifecycle.
An entity that, together with associated Representative Information (i.e., metadata), is produced or used in a research study
yToolTip: Considerations for Data Objects

aToolTip: Findability, Accessibility, Interoperability, Reuse: a set of guiding principles to support the reusability of data that are beneficial to all scholarly digital research objects.
yToolTip: Considerations for FAIR

aToolTip: Factors to take into account prior to conducting a research study
yToolTip: Considerations for Data/Metadata Considerations

aToolTip: The fundamental structure of an organization's research data management (RDM) system embodied in its components, their relationships to each other and to the environment, and the principles guiding its design and evolution. Includes, for example, the underlying storage technologies, networking, hardware, system interfaces, authentication mechanisms, data brokers, monitoring platforms, semantic interoperability tools, long-term preservation services, and HPC.
yToolTip: Considerations for Data Architecture

aToolTip: The physical and non-physical functional components that collectively form a foundation for conducting research and RDM
yToolTip: Considerations for Hardware and Software Infrastructure

aToolTip: Documents, including codes, specifications, recommended practices, classifications, test methods and guides, that describe how data should be stored or exchanged for the consistent collection and interoperability of that data across different systems, sources, and users.
yToolTip: Considerations for Research Data Standards

aToolTip: Evaluation of the success of a research project against expectations set before the project has started
Engagement and interactions among groups and Individual working in similar research areas
yToolTip: Considerations for Communication and Outreach

text: Access Control Associated with Data Sensitivity
aToolTip: Methods and requirements to limit the individuals and groups permitted to view or use protected data.
Classifications or categories of data, each with unique collection, generation, and storage challenges
yToolTip: Considerations for Data Types

aToolTip: Where and from which processes data originates
yToolTip: Considerations for Data Sources

aToolTip: Collection of information through active intervention by the researcher to induce and measure changes or to create differences when a variable is altered
yToolTip: Considerations for Generated Experimental Data

aToolTip: Production of information resulting from executing a computer model or simulation
yToolTip: Considerations for Generated Computational Data

aToolTip: Non-ordinal and focusing on qualities or characteristics
yToolTip: Considerations for Qualitative Data

aToolTip: Obtained from a source outside of the researchers and which was not originally collected for the current research project
yToolTip: Considerations for Acquired Data

aToolTip: Collected and processed in a standardized way with rigorous methodology to serve as a standard
yToolTip: Considerations for Critically Evaluated (CE) Data

aToolTip: Compliance with a set of guiding principles proposed by a consortium of scientists and organizations to support the reusability of digital assets
yToolTip: Considerations for FAIR Principles

aToolTip: Technical specifications for encoding metadata for machine processing and exchange
yToolTip: Considerations for Community-Based Standards

aToolTip: Programs that enable the collection and procurement of data
yToolTip: Considerations for Acquisition Software

aToolTip: Activities that result in Institution has a clearly defined high-level policies for research data management

text: RDM organization to support data-related activities exists
aToolTip: Activities that result in RDM organization to support data-related activities exists

zToolTip: E.1.3 Data management organization : An RDM infrastructure (RDMI) of human and capital resources that supports data-related activities, e.g., policies, planning, and sharing, as well as practices and projects, e.g., data acquisition, control, and protection.

text: Institution has a clearly defined statement of purpose and value for research data
aToolTip: Activities that result in Institution has a clearly defined statement of purpose and value for research data

zToolTip: E.1.5 Data management value proposition : A clear statement that indicates exactly what benefits an organization will derive from an RDM program. [12]

text: Data needs assessment completed at the desired level of analysis including: researcher, student, discipline, institution, unit, library

text: investigate existing grant funded projects and grants
Organizational intent regarding FAIR data is well defined across the institution and contributes to vision and policy
aToolTip: Activities that result in Organizational intent regarding FAIR data is well defined across the institution and contributes to vision and policy
zToolTip: E.1.8 Organization intent regarding FAIR data : The extent to which an organization supports the internal adoption and use of the FAIR data principles.

text: Support for end users included in institutional RDM and data governance standards
aToolTip: Activities that result in Support for end users included in institutional RDM and data governance standards
zToolTip: E.1.9 End-use support : Components of the RDMI within an organization that enable data to be prepared and processed for its ultimate application, including reuse.

text: Data governance legal policies, framework, and plans exist and are continually updated
aToolTip: Activities that result in Data governance legal policies, framework, and plans exist and are continually updated
zToolTip: E.2.1 Privacy : The practice of protecting and properly handling sensitive data, including personal, proprietary, and confidential data

zToolTip: E.2.7 Sharing/licensing : Data sharing agreement: A formal contract that details what data are being shared and the appropriate use for the data. Licensing agreement: A formal contract that states the purpose and duration of access being provided to the recipient licensee along with restriction and security protocols the recipient licensee of the data must follow. [22, 23]

zToolTip: E.2.8 Social license for use and reuse : An unwritten agreement whereby a group of public stakeholders accept that certain datasets may be applied for purposes other than those for which the data were originally intended, e.g., healthcare data. [24]

zToolTip: E.3.10 CARE and ethics : The CARE (Collective benefit, Authority to control, Responsibility, and Ethics) Principles for Indigenous Data Governance are people and purpose-oriented, reflecting the crucial role of data in advancing Indigenous innovation and self-determination. (These principles complement the existing FAIR principles for indigenous data governance.)   Ethics: Moral principles pertaining to data practices, e.g., analysis and dissemination, that have the potential to adversely impact people and society (e.g., to minimize bias and maintain the privacy of personal data). [15, 30]

text: Data Management Planning is expected from all research projects
aToolTip: Activities that result in Data Management Planning is expected from all research projects
zToolTip: P.3.1 Written data management plans (DMPs) : Documents that provide sufficient detail on the following topics: Administrative Data, Data Collection, Documentation and Metadata, Ethics and Legal Compliance, Storage and Backup, Selection and Preservation, Data Sharing, and Responsibilities and Resources. DMPs are referred to herein as a research data "roadmaps." [40]

text: Research data architecture includes machine-readable DMPs to standardize and automate capture RDM process
aToolTip: Activities that result in Research data architecture includes machine-readable DMPs to standardize and automate capture RDM process
zToolTip: P.3.4 Machine-readable DMPs : Research data roadmap documents in a form that can be used and understood by a computer. [41]

text: Research data architecture enables linkage of machine-readable DMPs other institutional data systems
aToolTip: Activities that result in Research data architecture enables linkage of machine-readable DMPs other institutional data systems
zToolTip: P.3.5 Linkage of DMPs to administrative records : Interconnection of a research data roadmaps to operational data, e.g., agreements, transactions.

text: Appropriate repository is determined to for data deposit to facilitate future access (institutional repository, shared repository, domain-specific or generalist)
aToolTip: Activities that result in Appropriate repository is determined to for data deposit to facilitate future access (institutional repository, shared repository, domain-specific or generalist)
zToolTip: P.3.6 Data organization in, e.g., a database and a repository, to facilitate future access : The practice of categorizing, classifying, and storing data with sufficient detail and specificity such that the data are readily discoverable and usable by others. [42]

text: Research data project participants have necessary RDM expertise and access to RDM training
aToolTip: Activities that result in Research data project participants have necessary RDM expertise and access to RDM training

text: Data objects and their representation metadata should be documented to maintain accuracy, integrity, and reliability
aToolTip: Activities that result in Data objects and their representation metadata should be documented to maintain accuracy, integrity, and reliability
zToolTip: P.4.7 Documentation (text) : Comprehensive information that accompanies a dataset, including all associated metadata, data dictionary, description of methods and instruments [and software used to generate/collect and] process the data, and other supporting data (e.g., duplicate sample results, replicate analyses). [48]
